coredata.dc:title: Integrated multi-scale modeling of variant selection during stress-induced martensite formation in metastable β Ti-alloys
coredata.prism:copyright: © 2022 The Authors. Published by Elsevier Ltd on behalf of Acta Materialia Inc.
coredata.prism:publisher: The Authors. Published by Elsevier Ltd on behalf of Acta Materialia Inc.
coredata.dc:creator: Niessen, Frank
Bhattacharyya, Abhishek
Gazder, Azdiar A.
Pereloma, Elena V.
Lebensohn, Ricardo A.
coredata.dc:description:
Stress-induced martensite formation is the predominant mechanism during the deformation of various functional and structural Ti- alloys. To predict the performance of these alloys, stress-induced martensite formation was modeled as a function of crystal orientation and stress state. We present an integrated micromechanical modeling approach using finite element (FE) analysis and an elastic spectral solver based on Fast Fourier Transforms (EFFT), which allows direct correlation of the available work from martensite formation under complex stress-states in an in-situ characterized microstructure. The model is applied as a virtual analogue of an experimental 3-point bending test of a metastable β Ti–10V–2Fe–3Al alloy containing 5% α. The FE model incorporates the experimental β microstructure from electron backscattering diffraction (EBSD) with anisotropic elastic behavior. The EFFT solver uses strain fields in two local regions from the FE model to predict local stresses in experimental microstructures containing β and α phases. The stress and orientation data are used to predict the available work from stress-induced
α
″
martensite formation of the six different
α
″
variants. It was found that stress and available work concentrated around the tips of lamellar α , making these regions preferred nucleation sites for
α
″
formation, which is in excellent agreement with the in-situ experimental observations. This suggests that the local stress conditions in the β phase play a more important role in triggering
α
″
formation than the compositional inhomogeneity in the β phase at α - β interfaces. Using the integrated model, the first variants forming at low levels of deformation could be confidently predicted. However, the transformation behavior at elevated levels of deformation could not be properly captured. This indicates the need of further model improvement, including Dirichlet boundary conditions for the EFFT solver and accounting for the role of plasticity induced by phase transformation.

Stress-induced martensite formation
Available work
Finite element analysis
Fast-Fourier transform

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) Montage of optical micrographs of the specimen cross section after bending. The specimen directions are indicated by the coordinate system. The bending load (F) was applied with an indenter and the two supports (separation distance = 8.2 mm) were positioned on the opposite side, leading to sample bending. The measured residual plastic bending along the symmetry axis after the test was 320 µm. The boxed regions indicate regions from which the EBSD maps were acquired. (b) Load-displacement plot indicating the load levels at which the EBSD maps were acquired, and FE analysis (FEA) was performed. The Fig. is an adaption of Figs 1 and 2b in Ref. [14].

Finite element model of the bending setup shown in Fig. 1. A symmetry region is defined along the indenter axis to reduce the overall number of elements. The image shows adaptive meshing in critical contact areas. The orientations of β grains are shown relative to the x-axis and represent element groups with anisotropic elastic properties and local coordinate systems. The inset demonstrates the mesh-resolution for the brick elements that were imported from EBSD data and shows three examples of local coordinate systems. Detailed in-situ EBSD and EFFT-based micromechanical analysis were conducted in regions EBSD1 and EBSD2. Copyright 2021, Elsevier. reproduced with permission from Ref. [14].

article.ce:title: Integrated multi-scale modeling of variant selection during stress-induced martensite formation in metastable β Ti-alloys

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para:
Stress-induced martensite formation is the predominant mechanism during the deformation of various functional and structural Ti- alloys. To predict the performance of these alloys, stress-induced martensite formation was modeled as a function of crystal orientation and stress state. We present an integrated micromechanical modeling approach using finite element (FE) analysis and an elastic spectral solver based on Fast Fourier Transforms (EFFT), which allows direct correlation of the available work from martensite formation under complex stress-states in an in-situ characterized microstructure. The model is applied as a virtual analogue of an experimental 3-point bending test of a metastable β Ti–10V–2Fe–3Al alloy containing 5% α. The FE model incorporates the experimental β microstructure from electron backscattering diffraction (EBSD) with anisotropic elastic behavior. The EFFT solver uses strain fields in two local regions from the FE model to predict local stresses in experimental microstructures containing β and α phases. The stress and orientation data are used to predict the available work from stress-induced
α
″
martensite formation of the six different
α
″
variants. It was found that stress and available work concentrated around the tips of lamellar α , making these regions preferred nucleation sites for
α
″
formation, which is in excellent agreement with the in-situ experimental observations. This suggests that the local stress conditions in the β phase play a more important role in triggering
α
″
formation than the compositional inhomogeneity in the β phase at α - β interfaces. Using the integrated model, the first variants forming at low levels of deformation could be confidently predicted. However, the transformation behavior at elevated levels of deformation could not be properly captured. This indicates the need of further model improvement, including Dirichlet boundary conditions for the EFFT solver and accounting for the role of plasticity induced by phase transformation.

ce:section.ce:para:
Stress-induced martensite formation is a prominent deformation mechanism in several metastable β Ti- alloys. Depending on the Ti alloy composition, phase transformation from the body-centered cubic (bcc) β phase to the orthorhombic
α
″
martensite enables superelasticity [1–3] or dynamic work-hardening [4–6]. To systematically design new alloys with specifically targeted mechanical properties,
α
″
formation requires modeling as a function of applied stress and β grain orientation. In alloys that show stress-induced martensite formation, one approach is to calculate the work that is made available by the martensitic transformation. The criterion for available work from stress-induced martensite formation was first introduced by Patel & Cohen [7] and has since been applied to analyze martensite formation in steels [8–10], in Cu-Al-Ni [11] and Ti-alloys [12,13]. In those analyses, the available work criterion was applied to texture data or individual grain orientations of the parent phase. However, since the stress fields within the transforming grains were generally assumed to be equal to the applied stress in those studies, an error was introduced in those analyses. In recent work by Niessen et al. [14], the available work from β -to-
α
″
transformation was calculated using averaged stresses from β -grains in a finite element (FE) model predicting martensitic variant selection during the in-situ 3-point bending of a metastable β Ti-10-2Fe-3Al with 5% α phase. The complex stress fields within the bending sample required a virtual analogue of the experiment to predict the local stress fields.

In the present work, we extend this approach by mapping the available work from β -to-
α
″
transformation directly on its sub-micron scale microstructural domains for the first time. To this end, an integrated model consisting of an FE model, an elastic Fast Fourier Transform (FFT)-based (EFFT) model, and an available work criterion, acts as a virtual analogue of an experimental in-situ 3-point bending test [14]. The integration of these various models is required to account for the complex boundary conditions of a 3-point bending test and to map the stresses and strains from the millimeter and micron scale of the bending sample to the nano scale of the α - β microstructure. The variant selection observed with electron backscattering diffraction (EBSD) and forward-scattering electron imaging is used to validate the predictions of the integrated model, and the modeling results are compared with the ones obtained by the simpler approach in Ref. [14]. The limitations and future possibilities for improving the integrated model are discussed in depth.

The experimental data from Ref. [14] is used to obtain the input parameters for the integrated model and to validate the predicted variant selection. Previously, Niessen et al. [14] reported stress-induced
α
″
martensite formation in a metastable β Ti-10-2Fe-3Al alloy containing 5% α , observed by in-situ forward-scattering electron imaging and EBSD. Fig. 1 (a) shows the deformed sample with a schematic of the setup consisting of two supports and an indenter applying a load from the opposite side. The regions at which orientation and phase data were acquired via EBSD are marked by the boxed regions. EBSD0 is a coarse overview map collected using a 1µm step size before loading the sample. EBSD1 and EBSD2 are high-resolution maps of the deformed and transformed microstructure acquired at different load levels collected using a 100 nm step size. Fig. 1(b) shows the load-displacement curve of the in-situ experiment and indicates the load levels at which maps EBSD1 and EBSD2 were acquired. It is apparent that bending up to map EBSD1 at 1500 N was macroscopically elastic, whereas the continued loading up to map EBSD2 at 2300 N led to plastic deformation. This is also evident from the residual displacement of 320 µm indicated in Fig. 1(a). More details on the experimental procedure and results can be found in Ref. [14].

The prediction of
α
″
variant selection via the available work model requires computation of the local stress fields in the α - β microstructure of the high-resolution orientation maps EBSD1 and EBSD2 (see Fig. 1). The complex geometry, boundary conditions and inhomogeneous stress state of the 3-point bending setup in combination with the high spatial resolution that is required to resolve the small α grains presents a challenge that requires the integration of two mechanical models, as visualized in the flow chart in Fig. 2 .

The large and coarse β orientation map EBSD0 is integrated into an isotropic FE model of the bending setup (see Section 2.2.1), yielding the stress field in this large region. The FE model is capable of accepting inhomogeneous boundary conditions and a realistic geometry representing the testing setup, but is not capable of determining the local stresses in the fine
α + β
microstructure, as the required resolution of the mesh would require unreasonable data acquisition and computational times (see the detailed discussion in Section 5.1). Therefore, the average strains in regions EBSD1 and EBSD2 are used as homogeneous boundary conditions for an EFFT model. While this model is limited to simple geometries and homogeneous boundary conditions, it efficiently maps the local stresses in smaller, high-resolution α - β orientation maps EBSD1 and EBSD2. The predicted local stress and strain fields at the
α + β
microstructural scale are then used as input for the available work calculations. The following sections contain details on the individual models.

A static structural 3-dimensional (3D) FE model in Fig. 3 was created in ANSYS Workbench 19.1 and its geometry consisted of the sample, the supports, and the indenter. A reflection symmetry boundary condition was defined along the indenter axis to reduce the computational costs of the model. The fixed supports and the indenter were modeled with elastically isotropic material properties of structural steel, assuming a Young's modulus of 200 GPa, and were in constant contact with the sample, thereby allowing for sliding over the sample surface with no friction. The indenter load was applied as a surface load across the upper side of the indenter along y . With the exception of the sample microstructure, all components were modeled using the elastically isotropic material properties of β phase in Table 1 , determined for the same alloy subjected to uniaxial tension [6]. The mesh of these components consisted of coarse tetrahedron elements which were locally refined at critical contact regions.

The maximum tensile and compressive bending stresses are expected in the sample section below the indenter. To create a virtual analogue that is a sympathetic reproduction of the real experiment, the region below the indenter was modeled by including the
β
microstructure from the actual experiment and considering anisotropic elastic properties (see the microstructure region in Fig. 3). The elastically anisotropic material properties in Table 1 were determined using in-situ neutron diffraction performed on the same alloy subjected to uniaxial tension [6]. The
β
microstructure map EBSD0 (Fig. 1(a)) from Ref. [14] spanned an area of 1450 × 1700 µm2 at a step size of 1 µm and was acquired before any load was applied. It was then cleaned by removing small inclusions and filled-in to only contain β orientations. Finally, the spatial resolution was reduced by a factor 4 to yield a feasible grid resolution for FE analysis. The map was converted to brick elements of
4
×
4
×
120
μ m
by adapting the procedure in Refs. [15,16]. The mean orientation of β grains was then assigned to the associated element groups*
⁎ The open-source computer program for mesh-generation for the ANSYS software is available from Ref. [32]. . The microstructure was integrated into the FE model by a bonded contact, allowing no sliding or separation between faces or edges and thus enabling a linear solution. The microstructure was framed by a region of tetrahedral elements that ensured a smooth transition from the scale of the small brick elements and the larger tetrahedral elements of the bulk of the sample. The overall number of nodes and elements in the FE model were
1.30
×
10
6
and
0.83
×
10
6
, respectively. The sensitivity of the mesh was investigated by ensuring that no discontinuities in stress were visible in the isotropic material region across adjacent elements. The tensile and compressive bending loads were furthermore validated by comparison with an analytical solution.

Compared to a purely elastic isotropic treatment of the problem, the incorporation of the β microstructure is expected to return a more precise estimate of the local stresses and strains. Since the β microstructure was only characterized in two dimensions, it needed to be simplified by a columnar microstructure in the 3D FE model. Given that the β grains in this alloy are coarse (200 ± 130 µm) and surface stresses in the integrated model are used to analyze martensitic transformation close to the surface in the experiment, the error introduced by reducing to a 2-dimensional (2D) microstructure is deemed manageable. The unconstrained surface in the FE model led to unconstrained deformation in the direction of the surface normal and thus led to a plane stress condition, which is a suitable representation of the surface stresses encountered in the experiment.

The EFFT model solves for the local distribution of strains and stresses on the in-situ orientation and phase maps EBSD1 and EBSD2 that were presented in Ref. [14]. The maps EBSD1 and EBSD2 were acquired at 1500 and 2300 N bending load, respectively, and covered an area of 150 × 200 µm at a resolution of 100 × 100 nm each. Their positions within the coarse map EBSD 0 are highlighted in Fig. 3.

Fig. 4 (a) and (d) show the phase maps of EBSD1 and EBSD2 overlaid on their band contrast maps. β forms the matrix phase while α decorates the β - β grain boundaries and forms as inclusions in the matrix. Both maps also show stress-induced
α
″
martensite which has exclusively formed during bending [14]. The amount of
α
″
is significantly higher in map EBSD 2, which has been exposed to more plastic deformation. Fig. 4 (b, c) and (e, f) show the β and α grain orientations with respect to the longitudinal axis of the sample, x. The
α
″
phase was removed from the dataset and filled-in with local β orientations. This was done to identify local stress concentrations in the untransformed sample at an applied load with the aim of predicting variant selection of
α
″
. Although filling-in orientation and phase data evidently led to some minor artefacts in the orientation data, it did not have any notable effect on subsequent analysis.

The microstructure data from Fig. 4 (b, c) and (e, f) was the starting point of the microstructure input files for the EFFT model. The domain was subject to periodic boundary conditions across the unit cell boundaries, which is an inherent condition of the FFT-based models. The effect of microstructure discontinuity at the boundaries in the x- and y-directions on the computed available work is discussed later. In the z-direction, the EFFT model consisted of 5 identical layers of the 2D microstructure maps, and 3 layers of a “buffer zone” or “gas phase” (Fig. 4 (g)). This buffer of infinite compliance disconnects the surface from the bottom of the periodic repetition of the microstructure layers and thereby allows for a consistent plane stress condition with the experiment and FE model [18].

The openMP implementation [19] of the elasto-viscoplastic (EVPFFT) model of Lebensohn et al. [20] was run over 12 threads, using boundary conditions from the FE analysis and microstructure input files corresponding to Fig. 4 (g). The plastic yield by dislocation slip was set to very large values to effectively eliminate its contribution and render the model purely elastic (going forward referred to as EFFT). Details of the FFT-based model are not repeated here. Instead, the interested reader is referred to the original work in Ref. [20] or subsequent review papers (e.g. [21]) on FFT-based formulations for polycrystalline materials. A plane stress boundary condition was imposed in the z-direction and orthotropic elastic material properties were applied for α and β as listed in Table 1.

Available work analysis was applied to predict the work that is made available by the shape deformation of the martensitic transformation in response to an applied stress. The mathematical criterion for the available work, U , was first introduced by Patel & Cohen [7] and is given by:
(1)
U = t r
(
P
σ
)
where P is the shape strain of the martensitic transformation, σ is the applied stress tensor and
t r ( x )
is the trace of x .

In the present study, Eq. (1) is applied to each pixel of the topmost layer of the EFFT grid using the mean grain orientation and the local stress tensor to determine the spatial distribution of U within the microstructure. The shape strain P is approximated by the Bain strain, which only deviates negligibly from the actual shape strain in the present transformation system [22]:
(2)
P =
[
λ 1
0
0
0
λ 2
+
λ 3
2
λ 3
−
λ 2
2
0
λ 3
−
λ 2
2
λ 2
+
λ 3
2
]
P is defined in the β basis and the principal lattice strains are given by:
(3)
λ 1
=
a
α
″
−
a β
a β
,
λ 2
=
b
α
″
−
2
a β
2
a β
and
λ 3

c
α
″

2

2
a β

The lattice parameters of
α
″
and β were determined with neutron diffraction for the same alloy in Ref. [6] and are given in Table 2 .

P is defined with respect to the β crystal coordinate system for
α
″
variant 1. Applying the rotation matrices in Table 3 to P , the shape strains for each of the six variants are obtained. Since σ is obtained by the EFFT model with respect to the specimen coordinate system, the σ tensors are rotated into the β crystal coordinate system by applying the mean grain orientations of β .

It is well known that martensite formation on a free surface requires a lower activation energy [23] and that its variant selection is different from the variant selection expected in the bulk [24]. In this work, the surface strains and stresses are computed under a plane stress condition on the surface such that the available work model takes aspects of the surface effect on martensite formation into account.

Fig. 5 shows the principal stress components from FE analysis at 690 N indenter load superimposed with the grain boundaries. 690 N was chosen as a representative load within the macroscopically elastic region of the load-displacement curve (see Fig. 1 (b)). As expected, the bending stress,
σ 11
, along x , shows compression in the upper region and tension in the lower region of the sample as well as a neutral zone with
σ 11
≅ 0
N
in the center region.
σ 22
shows significant compressive stress in the vicinity of the sample-indenter contact area while the remaining region shows low tensile or compressive stress.
σ 33
is approximately 0 N, as the deformation of the surface grains is not constrained in z . The shear component
σ 12
shows local stress concentrations along grain boundaries, caused by elastic incompatibility. Similar behavior is visible for the shear components,
σ 23
and
σ 31
, albeit at stress values close to 0 MPa.
Mean strain tensors were extracted from regions EBSD1 and EBSD2 in Fig. 5 (c) to serve as boundary conditions for the EFFT analysis and are listed in Table 4 .

Fig. 6 shows the von Mises elastic stress distributions in the microstructures EBSD1 and EBSD2 from EFFT analysis with the strain boundary conditions from FE analysis at 690 N in Table 4 and a plane stress boundary condition in the z-direction. The local stresses were intentionally not modeled at the load levels at which maps EBSD1 and EBSD2 were captured, as the microstructure would have already been plastically deformed and transformed. The macroscopic von Mises stresses from EFFT analysis were 128 MPa for EBSD1 and 94 MPa for EBSD2. The local von Mises stresses depicted in Fig. 6 show a mostly homogeneous distribution with increased stress concentrated at α - β and β - β interfaces (with the latter also decorated with α ) and within some α grains. In a previous in-situ neutron diffraction experiment study on the same alloy [6], the macroscopic triggering stress for
α
″
formation during uniaxial tension was determined as 215 MPa. Even though the macroscopic von Mises stresses from EFFT lie significantly below this critical value at 690 N indenter load, the triggering stress for
α
″
formation is exceeded in various localized regions, which in turn, could trigger nucleation of
α
″
.

Figs. 7 and 8
show the principal stress components of maps EBSD1 and EBSD2 from EFFT analysis, respectively. The mean stress components in the β matrix are in excellent agreement with the stresses from FE analysis in the same regions (compare with Fig. 5). EBSD1, located in the compressive zone, shows a dominant principal stress
σ 11
in compression. EBSD2, located close to the neutral zone, shows a bending stress
σ 11
close to 0 MPa and a dominant shear component
σ 12
. It is evident that stress concentrates at α - β interfaces. The periodic boundary conditions of the EFFT algorithm also led to artefact stresses at the unit cell boundaries (for instance, see the lower right corner of
σ 11
or the upper right corner of
σ 12
in Fig. 7).

The available work was computed using Eq. (1) along with the mean β grain orientations from Fig. 4 (b) and (e), the stress maps from Figs. 7 and 8, and the transformation strains from Eq. (2) using the symmetry operations from Table 3 as input. For each pixel of the orientation map, the maximum available work,
U
m a x
, is determined from the available work, U , of all 6 variants:
(4)
U max
= max
( U )

Fig. 9
shows
U
m a x
for maps EBSD1 and EBSD2. While the previous stress plots depicted somewhat homogeneous stress fields over the entire domain,
U
m a x
shows a clear dependence on the different β grain orientations. The strong effect of the β grain orientation on
U
m a x
was previously emphasized in a computational modeling study, in which
U
m a x
was systematically mapped as a function of grain orientation and stress state [12].

It is evident that peak stresses at some of the α - β interfaces also translated into higher available work. In some regions, the sharp tips of the α grains were especially associated with high available work (see boxed region in Fig. 9 (a)). Regions with high
U
m a x
should serve as potent nucleation sites for
α
″
. The consistency of this hypothesis with the experimental observations is discussed in Section 5.2.

Figs. 10 and 11
show the available work, U , for each of the 6
α
″
variants in maps EBSD1 and EBSD2, respectively. Compared to the plot for
U
m a x
, each variant also has regions of negative available work. When a particular variant shows negative available work in a certain region, the nucleation of this variant would lead to an increase in the local stress and would therefore not serve as a valid deformation mode. As in Fig. 9 , the available work of each variant also shows a high dependency on the β grain orientation. The stress artefacts that were caused by the periodicity of the microstructure by the boundary conditions of the EFFT model seem to leave the available work largely unaffected. An exception to this is the area of locally increased available work located at the right unit cell boundary of map EBSD2 (Fig. 9 (b)). Compared to the individual components U ,
U
m a x
is further dampened by only considering the maximum value at each microstructure coordinate.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Experimental validation of the integrated available work model
ce:section.ce:para:
To determine which variants are most favored in the different β grains, the distributions of U are plotted for the individual β grains and compared with the experimentally observed
α
″
variants from Ref. [14]. To simplify the comparison, the available work of the six variants that was mapped onto the microstructural maps in Figs. 10 and 11 are represented as distributions in histograms in Figs. 12 and 14.

EBSD1 is a region in which the bending stress,
σ 11
, is predominant and compressive. Fig. 12 compares the distribution of the available work in the three β -grains of map EBSD1 with the experimentally observed variants. In grain
β 1
, the model makes a prediction of high available work for variants 1 and 2, which is in excellent agreement with the variants observed in the experiment.

In grain
β 3
, variant 2 is dominant in the microstructure and also returned the highest available work in the calculations. However, the situation was less clear than in grain
β 1
, as several variants had small positive values of available work. The second variant that formed in the microstructure was variant 2, which also showed positive available work. It is evident that variant 2 only formed in the vicinity of the
β 1
grain boundary, suggesting that the local stress state favored its formation. This local increase of available work was however not predicted by the integrated available work model (Fig. 10(a)). The local stress field may therefore be caused by the back stresses of the already transformed martensitic units, which are not accounted for in the model. The remaining variants having positive available work, variants 4 and 5, were not observed in the experiment at all. For grain
β 2
, variants 3 and 4 were predicted to have high available work. While the formation of variant 3 was indeed observed experimentally, variants 1 and 6 formed via self-accommodation instead of variant 4. This transformation behavior is not straight-forward to explain and was not captured by the model. It appears that grain
β 1
being closest to the indenter-sample contact point (see Fig. 1(a)), transformed first and may thereby have affected the stress state in
β 2
.

The predictions made with the simpler model in Ref. [14] in which the available work was calculated using β-grain-averaged stresses from a FE model, are similar to the ones obtained by the present integrated model in the case of grains
β 1
and
β 2
. In the case of
β 3
, a high positive work for variants 1 and 2 and high negative available work for variant 3 are predicted. This suggests that the spurious effects by the periodic grain boundary seem to notably affect the available work in this grain.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Map EBSD2 – neutral zone with high shear
ce:section.ce:para:
EBSD2 is a region in which the bending stress is almost zero, and the major stress component is
σ 12
. On top of the EBSD dataset of region EBSD2, acquired at the maximum indenter load 2300 N, the image series in Fig. 13 was acquired progressively during loading. The image series reveals the nucleation sequence of the different
α
″
plates. Comparison with the final EBSD data reveals their variant identities. The nucleation sequence of the different variants for region EBSD2 is summarized in Table 5 and is important for the validation of the integrated available work model for variant prediction, as in this way the effect of backstresses from
α
″
formation on the confidence of the variant prediction can be assessed. Fig. 14 compares the predictions from the available work model with the experimentally observed variants.

Fig. 14(a) shows that, in grain
β 4
, variants 3, 4 and 5 are predicted to have positive available work. Of those variants, the ones with the highest available work, variants 3 and 4, were also observed experimentally. From Fig. 13 and Table 5, it is apparent that grain
β 4
already transformed at a relatively low indenter load of 1540 N and that variants 3 and 4 were the first to form. At increased load (> 1735 N), variant 6 subsequently formed. This variant was predicted to be unfeasible by the available work model. It is therefore likely that the backstresses of variants 3 and 4 generated locally favorable stress conditions for nucleation of variant 6.

Grain
β 7
transformed already at a low indenter load of 1540 N as well. Over most of the bending test, grain
β 7
only formed variants 1 and 2 (Fig. 13 and Table 5). This is in excellent agreement with the prediction from the available work model, which only predicts these variants to be feasible with a high magnitude of available work (Fig. 14). During the last two loading steps, variants 4 and 5 also formed, which could not be captured by the available work model. Apparently, the stress state in the microstructure diverges from the linear elastic stress state of the non-transforming mechanical model towards high deformation.

Grain
β 6
formed variant 6 quite early on (Fig. 13 and Table 5) at an indenter load > 1735 N, and at a later stage of deformation formed variants 1 and 6 via self-accommodation at an indenter load > 2025 N. Neither of these variants were predicted as favorable by the available work model (Fig. 14). The available work was quite low for any of the possible variants, which agrees with transformation of this grain at a high degree of deformation. At this stage, the model however seems to be incapable of predicting variant selection correctly. Fig. 13 shows that
α
″
in grain
β 6
nucleated outside of the region of interest in the lower right corner of the image. Therefore, the transformation to variant 6 may possibly have been triggered by a local stress state in this external region, which is inaccessible to the model.

Grain
β 5
shows similar behavior to grain
β 6
. Grain
β 5
only began transforming at a late stage of bending (Fig. 13 and Table 5) at an indenter load > 1915 N. At first, variant 3 formed locally at the grain boundary, then variant 2, as well as variants 2, 3 and 5 formed via self-accommodation. In the final load step variant 4 also formed. The available work model almost predicted the exact opposite variants to be feasible (Fig. 14), which is a poor prediction. Like grain
β 6
, the overall available work for any variant was quite low and the resulting variant selection was a complex self-accommodated martensitic structure.

The predictions made with the simpler model in Ref. [14] in which the available work was calculated using β -grain-averaged stresses, are similar to the ones obtained by the present integrated model in all of the four β grains. From these observations it appears that when none of the 6 variants are particularly favored, an above average stress is required for the martensitic transformation, and that the resulting martensitic structure is quite complex, which agrees with the observations in Ref. [14]. This is likely both an effect of the available work being spread over several variants, and the heterogeneous stress fields from plastically deforming the microstructure.

Finally, we observe that while the average available work for variant 3 in grain
β 5
was negative (Fig. 15 (a)), a small tail of the available work distribution showed positive available work (Fig. 15(b)). Examining the spatial distribution of the available work in map EBSD2 for variant 4, it becomes evident that the positive available work is located in a confined region close to the β triple junction (see Fig. 11(c) and the magnified region in Fig. 15(c)).

It is notable that this matches the region in which variant 3 formed experimentally (see Fig. 14(b) and the magnified region in Fig. 15(d)). As visible from Fig. 13(e), the variant was the first variant to form in this grain, matching the region of the highest
U
m a x
in grain
β 5
(Fig. 9(b)) and one of the few variants that did not form in self-accommodation. This encouraging observation is overshadowed by the artefact stresses that are generated by the periodic boundary conditions of the EFFT model close to this region (Fig. 8). It is difficult to say to which extent these stresses have affected the prediction.

The comparison of experimentally characterized and predicted variant selection in Section 4, shows that in some cases the integrated available work model is able to successfully predict variant selection in metastable β Ti alloys, whereas in other cases it failed to give a confident prediction.

The cases in which two variants are clearly favored leads to a high available work for these variants, caused by a favorable alignment of the local stress state with the common shear component of these two variants. In this case the transformation to those two
α
″
variants was observed at a relatively low level of deformation experimentally, showing good agreement with the model. In cases where the local stress state is not favorably aligned with the transformation strain of any of the variants, multiple variants are associated with small positive values of available work. In these cases, it was observed that the transformation of such grains indeed occurred at higher magnitudes of local stress, but that the prediction of variant selection was oftentimes incorrect. Finally, in grains where the first-forming variants were confidently predicted at low magnitudes of local stress, subsequent transformation at higher stress resulted in formation of additional variants which were also predicted incorrectly.

It therefore appears that, given the approximations needed to make the problem numerically tractable, the integrated model at present lacks the predictive capabilities to confidently predict variant selection, apart from the situation in which clearly favored variants form at low levels of deformation. While this at first sight might seem discouraging, the present investigation is a blueprint for how in-situ experimentation and computational models at several length scales can be closely integrated, and it reveals important shortcomings in the individual models and their integration to outline a clear direction for future development of such approaches. In this respect, the following sections discuss the different specific aspects.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Integration of the FE and EFFT models
ce:section.ce:para:
The FE and EFFT models were integrated to describe the mechanical response of the fine α - β microstructure at
100
×
100
n
m
2
resolution as an integrated part of the 3-point bending setup with a sample of
30
×
5
m
m
2
surface area. The EFFT model is computationally efficient, and one can argue that the entire microstructure could be managed by a large EFFT simulation at
100
×
100
n
m
2
resolution. However, there are at least two reasons why this is not feasible: (i) Acquisition of the large overview EBSD map at this resolution and scale would have taken ∼1200 h with the present setup and parameters. (ii) The EFFT model is currently not capable of modeling the complex geometry and boundary conditions that are required to create a virtual analogue of the 3-point bending experiment.

The integration of the fine microstructure, if experimentally achievable, into the FE model on the other hand would have led to an extremely fine mesh, increasing the computational cost by a factor of 1600. Furthermore, this numerical limitation of an FE-only analysis would be exacerbated if the present pure elastic analysis was extended - as it is our intention - to consider the more complex and numerically demanding transformation plasticity regime. In this regard, it will certainly be numerically advantageous to extend the FFT-based computations to consider different modes of plasticity when improving the integrated model in the future.

To conclude this discussion, it is worth noting that extensions of the FFT-based formulation with the ability to impose local values of the micromechanical fields at boundaries with arbitrary shapes are becoming available [25,26], which could in the future be applied to improve the present analysis.

ce:section.ce:section-title:
Nucleation and growth of
α
″
plates
ce:section.ce:para:
The available work model is based on the work that can be obtained by transforming a certain β grain of given orientation for a specific stress state to one of the six
α
″
variants. While this model has its merit and has predictive capabilities as demonstrated above, it does not explicitly consider the conditions for the nucleation of variants. Nevertheless, some aspects of nucleation may be captured by the model: Fig. 16 (a) shows a magnified region of the EBSD1 map of maximum available work,
U
m a x
, in Fig. 9(a). The image shows that higher values of available work extend from the tips of α grains into the β grain matrix. These fields of elevated available work values in front of α grains also appear to overlap with the ones of neighboring α grains. This heterogeneous distribution of maximum available work is a consequence of the stress concentrations observed at α - β interfaces (see Fig. 6(a)). Naturally, these regions could serve as heterogeneous nucleation sites for
α
″
. In the bending experiment, the nucleation of
α
″
was followed systematically in Fig. 16(b–f). The region is just above the EBSD2 map and is marked in Fig. 5(c). It is notable that almost all variants are nucleated at, intersect, or are in the vicinity of, α - β interfaces as indicated by the white arrows. While large regions with few α grains exist (for instance, the lower right area in Fig. 16(b–f)),
α
″
formation appears to be prefered in regions with a high population of α grains. It is likely that
α
″
formation is favorable along the locally concentrated stress fields which lead to increased available work in those localized regions as depicted in Fig. 16(a). This argument is further supported by the general observation that the β matrix is enriched in β -stabilizing elements in the vicinity of α - β interfaces [27]. Thus, despite the locally reduced chemical driving force for
α
″
formation via increased
β
phase stability, preferred nucleation is observed at α - β interfaces and should therefore be induced by the local increase in available work. The present results suggest that the local stress conditions in the β phase play a more important role in triggering
α
″
formation than the compositional inhomogeneity in the β phase.

When the nucleation of
α
″
is triggered by impinged
α
″
units in neighboring β grains, the phenomenon is termed as sympathetic nucleation (see red arrows in Fig. 16(d)). It is unclear whether the sympathetic nucleation mechanism also affects variant selection. The reliable prediction of variant selection at low bending loads by the available work model suggests that this might not be the case. A limitation of the available work model is that it does not account for the formation of
α
″
units. As a result, it therefore cannot predict the exact locations where such transformation will occur. Only the direct modeling of
α
″
formation in the β matrix and its effect on the local stress state would account for the sympathetic nucleation mechanism.

The microstructure input files to the FE and EFFT models are derived from 2D EBSD maps. Even though both mechanical models were set-up in 3D, the analysis was limited to the 2D surface microstructure characterized via in-situ EBSD. These stresses and strains are modulated by the stress and strain fields of the underlying microstructure, which cannot be assessed with the given data. Changes in these surface strains and stresses would influence the available work and the predicted variant selection. The large β grain size of 200 ± 130 µm in the investigated material reduces the error introduced by this simplification, as the surface microstructure is expected to extend far below the surface. Also, the
α
″
units that appear to nucleate at certain surface regions may also extend well below the surface and could have their nucleation site below the surface. This mechanism would have an increased effect with larger β grain size.

While these shortcomings affect the accuracy of the integrated available work model in the context of the present experimental dataset, it is encouraging that the model itself is set up in 3D and could be applied to 3D microstructure datasets without any modifications. The increasing availability of 3D synchrotron X-ray diffraction [28] and the currently active development of dark-field X-ray microscopy [29] motivates the application of this model in combination with these characterization techniques for in-situ deformation studies of phase-transforming materials in 3D.

ce:section.ce:section-title:
Plastic deformation and back stresses from
α
″
formation
ce:section.ce:para:
The present model was limited to the anisotropic elastic interaction of the microstructure components. It is clear from experimental observation that some of the applied indenter load led to plastic deformation (Fig. 1). However, it is not straight-forward to account for the observed plasticity in the model. An in-situ neutron diffraction study of the deformation and transformation behavior of this material under uniaxial tension [6] revealed a double-yielding behavior: the first yield point of the material at 215 MPa was associated with deformation-induced
α
″
martensite formation while the second yield-point at 700 MPa was associated with the onset of dislocation slip. Therefore implementation of plasticity from dislocation slip would only be reasonable if also the plasticity from
α
″
formation was accounted for. Implementing
α
″
formation as a mode of plasticity into the model could only be achieved when coupled with the available work model, as both have an interlinked effect on each other. The implementation of such a scheme is beyond the scope of this work. The only way to account for plasticity in the available work model would be to extend the EFFT full-field model to explicitly include the nucleation and growth of
α
″
plates. Such a model would account for the back stresses that are generated by the nucleation and growth of
α
″
plates, which in turn, may trigger new nucleation events (see Fig. 16(d)) and may affect variant selection by modulating the local available work for the different variants. In such an extension to the model, one could also allow dislocation slip as a deformation mechanism to account for local plasticity events. Two existing extensions of the FFT-based model, to the cases of concurrent martensitic phase transformation and plastic slip with simplified geometry [30] and deformation twinning and dislocation slip plasticity [31] could be used as basis for the aforementioned extended analysis.

We presented an integrated mechanical model that enabled the mapping of the local available work from deformation-induced
α
″
formation at the sub-micron scale in a metastable β Ti alloy subjected to 3-point bending at the mm-scale for the first time. This virtual analogue model locally resolved the available work from martensite formation for complex stress states to predict martensitic variant selection. The model was successful in its predictions, when only two variants were associated with positive available work, corresponding to a favorable alignment for transformation of the local stress with the transformation shear. In cases where the alignment of local stress and transformations strain was less favorable for transformation, several variants showed small positive values of available work and the transformation only occurred at higher local stress and in a more complex manner. In such cases, the model failed to predict variant selection, as effects of local plasticity and back stresses generated by
α
″
plates dominated the local stress fields. The model indicated that α - β interfaces were regions of increased available work and thereby potent sites for heterogeneous nucleation of
α
″
, which was consistent with corresponding in-situ experimental observations. This suggests that the local stress conditions in the β phase play a more important role in triggering
α
″
formation than the composition-induced increased stability of the β phase at α - β interfaces. The limitations of the proposed model and options for its future improvement were discussed. Since the model is formulated in 3D, some of the shortcomings of the present analysis can be overcome by pairing this model with in-situ deformation data from 3D synchrotron X-ray diffraction. Recent developments in the context of EFFT-based models to include Dirichlet boundary conditions [25,26] will enable a better integration of the FTT based and FE models.
